results.title: Walking the mob
results.creator_credit: Keith Fraser, ABC-TV (Australia) and Lionel Hudson
results.brief_description: The life and work of the cattle drovers shown as they take a big herd across central Australia. The drover’s way of lie in the outback Australia. A typical drover, Jack Jones, and his team bring a mob of 600 cattle from Bergmont Station in the Northern Territory to Longreach, Queensland. Their route follows the Thompson River, one of the country’s driest regions. Shows new and old methods of transporting cattle; one lot being walked and the other lot by train.

results.title: Walking in the sunlight, walking in the shadow
results.creator_credit: Joe Scully, Australian Commonwealth Film Unit and Bob Kingsbury
results.brief_description: Education and social integration of Northern Territory Aborigines. Considers the position of the Aboriginal in Australia, particularly in the Northern areas when the great bulk of the native population is located. The average Australian read about his plight in the newspaper and he sees programmes on television, but how is the situation viewed in the Northern Territory? Includes interviews with those involved and scenes of contemporary Aboriginal life.

results.title: Walking in a sacred manner: North American indians and the natural world
results.creator_credit: Stephen Cross, Tapovana Films, Derek Waterman and Tom McBride
results.brief_description: Told in their own words, this film provides a commentary on the American Indians’ way of life prior to the erosion of their cultural values by European civilization. Highlights their respect for the natural world and their appreciation of its importance to the physical, spiritual and psychological well-being of human beings. Photographs taken by Edward S. Curtis between 1896 and 1930 illustrate the traditional life of the Northwest plains and mountain Indians in its complete, authentic form. The commentary is selected from the words of: Black Elk, Brave Buffalo, Chief Flying Hawk, Chief Luther-Standing Bear, Chief Red Jacket, Chief Seattle. Music from “Songs and Dances of the Flathead Indians” and John Arlee.

results.title: Walking for physical fitness
results.brief_description: Explains the importance of correct footwear when walking, the benefits of walking and the pleasures walking can bring to all who participate. An informative and motivational film of those who enjoy walking as part of their recreational pursuits.

results.title: Walking country
results.creator_credit: Tom Williamson, New Zealand National Film Unit and Conon Fraser
results.brief_description: Mountains and forests cover more than half of New Zealand, and the country is served by a well-maintained network of walking tracks. With its varied scenery, New Zealand offers magnificent walking Country.

results.title: Walkaway prices
results.creator_credit: Tasmanian Film Corporation and Jack Zalkalns
results.brief_description: A dramatized re-enactment of an adolescent boy’s increasing involvement in petty theft and vandalism due to the peer pressure exerted on him by two other boys. His fears of being detected are eventually borne out when two detectives appear at the school and ask to see him. Cast includes: Robert Clarkson, Dam Suitable for lower and middle secondary levels.

results.title: Walkabout: the Chauvel's legendary journey...
results.brief_description: Originally produced for British television in 1958 this thirteen part series follows internationally renowned Australian filmmakers Charles Chauvel and Elsa Chauvel on a 3,000 mile journey through Australia. Setting off from Sydney they travel across the Great Dividing Range, heading westward to the outback “dead heart” of Australia through Central Australia and on to the Northern Territory. They look at the outback with all its “bewildering contradictions” - deserts, pasturelands, wide grasslands, opal country, mountain ranges and rivers - join a cattle muster, catch brumbies, observe unique wildlife and visit Aboriginal communities. The series is a time capsule of Australian outback life in the middle of the twentieth century reflecting the attitudes held by white Australians towards Aboriginal peoples and the land at the time. Narrated by Elsa and Charles Chauvel.
